user_request: Write a poem about a traveler at a fork in a yellow wood who chooses the less-traveled path.
final_poem:
Beneath the amber light of fading days,  
where shadows stretch and whispers weave,  
the traveler paused where two roads lay—  
one trod with footprints, one with leave.  

The first was worn by countless sighs,  
its gravel crunched with echoed names.  
The second, soft with mossy sighs,  
a ribbon lost in time’s slow frames.  

He traced the grooves where leaves had fallen,  
each step a weight of unseen cost.  
Yet in the hush, a pull was called—  
a path that dared to be the lost.  

So he chose the one that bent and braced,  
where wildflowers dared the wind to stay,  
and though the way was steep and frayed,  
it hummed with secrets no one knew.  

Now years have passed, and still he walks,  
the scarred terrain his compass keeps,  
for every step, a choice to spoke—  
the road less taken, never slept.
